title: Gargoyle Gecko Feeding Guide: Complete Diet & Schedules
description: Complete feeding guide for gargoyle geckos covering CGD (crested gecko diet) preparation, age-based schedules, insect supplementation, calcium dusting, and nutrition management.
excerpt: Complete feeding guide for gargoyle geckos covering CGD (crested gecko diet) preparation, age-based schedules, insect supplementation, calcium dusting, and nutrition management.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Feeding Your Gargoyle Gecko
content.content: Gargoyle geckos are omnivorous, requiring both fruit-based meal replacement powder (CGD - Crested Gecko Diet) and live insects. This guide covers complete nutrition including CGD brands, preparation, feeding schedules by age, insect supplementation, and portion management for healthy growth.

CGD is Not Optional: Unlike insectivorous species (leopard geckos, bearded dragons), gargoyle geckos REQUIRE fruit-based nutrition from CGD powder. Insects alone lack essential vitamins, calcium ratios, and fruit sugars needed for health. CGD must be the staple diet with insects as supplemental protein.

content.title: Crested Gecko Diet (CGD): The Staple Food

content.content: CGD powder is a complete meal replacement developed specifically for frugivorous geckos (gargoyle, crested, leachianus). It contains balanced protein, vitamins, minerals, and fruit components.

content.text: Recommended CGD Brands:

rows: Mango Superblend, Grubs 'N' Fruit, Banana Cream Pie

content.content: Brand Recommendations: Pangea Fig & Insects or Watermelon are gold standards. Repashy Grubs 'N' Fruit excellent for variety. Rotate 2-3 flavors to prevent pickiness and ensure balanced nutrition. Avoid relying solely on one brand/flavor.

content.text: CGD Preparation:

items: Ratio: Mix 1 part powder to 2 parts water by volume. Example: 1 teaspoon powder + 2 teaspoons water
Water Type: Filtered or dechlorinated tap water. Avoid distilled water (lacks minerals)
Consistency: Mix thoroughly until smooth - should resemble ketchup or baby food (thick but pourable). Lumps indicate insufficient mixing
Mixing Container: Use small lidded container or shot glass. Shake vigorously for 30-60 seconds
Batch Size: Prepare only what gecko will eat in 24-36 hours. Small batches prevent waste
Storage: Refrigerate unused powder after opening (extends freshness). Mixed CGD lasts 24-48 hours refrigerated in sealed container

content.text: Feeding Presentation:

items: Feeding Ledge: Use magnetic feeding ledge positioned mid-height (12-15 inches up). Gargoyle geckos prefer elevated feeding stations
Bowl Type: Small shallow dish or bottle cap (gecko licks food, doesn't need depth). Avoid dishes >2 inches tall
Portion Size: 1-2 teaspoons mixed CGD per feeding. Hatchlings <10g: 1/2 teaspoon; juveniles 10-30g: 1 teaspoon; adults 30g+: 1.5-2 teaspoons
Feeding Time: Offer in evening (6-9 PM) since gargoyle geckos are crepuscular (active dawn/dusk)
Removal: Remove uneaten CGD after 24 hours maximum. CGD molds quickly in humid environment (60-80% humidity)

rows: Focus on growth - CGD every night is critical. Never skip CGD days
CGD: 1 tsp; Insects: 3-5 small-medium (3/8" crickets, small dubia)
Rapid growth phase. Continue daily CGD until 12+ months
CGD: 1.5 tsp; Insects: 4-6 medium (1/2" crickets, medium dubia)
Transition to adult schedule gradually. Monitor weight
CGD: 1.5-2 tsp; Insects: 5-8 medium-large (1/2" crickets, adult dubia)
Adjust based on activity level. Breeding females need daily CGD
Increased nutrition for egg production. Monitor calcium levels closely

content.content: Feeding Frequency Key Point: Juveniles under 12 months need DAILY CGD for proper growth. Adults can eat every 2-3 days but should never go longer than 3 days between CGD meals. Insects are supplemental - gargoyle geckos can survive on CGD alone but insects provide behavioral enrichment and protein variety.
While CGD provides complete nutrition, live insects add protein variety, mental stimulation, and hunting enrichment. Offer insects 1-2x per week depending on age.

content.text: Best Insect Feeders:

rows: Illegal in some states (FL, HI), slower movement
Fast - can escape if not careful
High calcium:phosphorus ratio, no dusting needed
Long lifespan, slow movement, easy storage

content.content: AVOID These Feeders: NEVER feed wild-caught insects (pesticide risk), fireflies/lightning bugs (toxic), boxelder bugs (toxic), or king mealworms to geckos under 40g (too large, impaction risk). Also avoid superworms as regular feeders - high fat content causes obesity. Use superworms as occasional treats only.

content.text: Insect Size Guidelines:

items: Golden Rule: Insect length should NOT exceed distance between gecko's eyes (approximately 1/3 head width)
Hatchlings (0-10g): 1/4 inch crickets (pinheads), extra small dubia nymphs
Juveniles (10-30g): 3/8 inch crickets, small dubia (6-8mm)
Adults (40g+): 1/2 inch crickets, medium-large dubia (12-15mm), adult red runners
Oversized Consequences: Impaction (intestinal blockage), choking risk, refusal to eat

content.text: Gut-Loading Insects (48 Hours Before Feeding):

items: Purpose: Insects are nutritionally poor without gut-loading. Feeding insects quality food transfers nutrients to gecko
Commercial Gut-Load: Repashy Bug Burger, Fluker's High-Calcium Cricket Diet, Cricket Crack
DIY Gut-Load: Collard greens, squash, sweet potato, carrots, high-quality fish flakes. Avoid iceberg lettuce (no nutrients)
Timing: Feed insects heavily 24-48 hours before offering to gecko. Well-fed insects = better gecko nutrition
Hydration: Provide water crystals or fresh vegetables for insect hydration (dry insects less nutritious)

content.content: Gargoyle geckos need calcium supplementation when eating insects. CGD already contains calcium, so dusting is for insects only.

content.text: Supplement Schedule:

rows: Arcadia CalciumPro Mg, Rep-Cal, Zoo Med ReptiCalcium
Light dusting - insects should look lightly powdered (not breaded)
Rep-Cal with D3, Zoo Med with D3
Only use if NO UVB lighting. Overdose risk with UVB present
Repashy Calcium Plus (low D3), Arcadia EarthPro-A
Skip if gecko eating CGD regularly. Only supplement if refusing CGD >1 week

content.text: Dusting Technique:

items: Place insects in small plastic bag or cup with 1/4 teaspoon calcium powder
Shake gently 10-15 seconds until insects lightly coated (should still see insect color through powder)
Offer immediately - dusting wears off as insects groom themselves within 30 minutes
Do NOT over-dust - thick powder coating causes geckos to refuse insects
For multiple insects: Dust in batches to ensure even coating

content.content: D3 Toxicity Risk: If providing UVB lighting (12" T8 6% or ReptiSun 5.0), use calcium WITHOUT D3 only. Gargoyle geckos synthesize D3 from UVB exposure. Adding supplemental D3 when UVB present causes hypervitaminosis D3 (D3 overdose) - symptoms include lethargy, kidney damage, calcification of organs. NEVER double-supplement D3.
Gargoyle geckos can have occasional treats for enrichment and dietary variety. Treats should comprise <10% of total diet.

content.text: Safe Treats (1-2x per month):

items: Pinkie Mice (frozen/thawed): Size: newborn pinkie for adults 40g+ only. High calcium, protein, fat - excellent for breeding females. Offer 1x monthly maximum (very high fat)
Fruit Purees: Mashed banana, papaya, mango, or fig mixed into CGD (80% CGD + 20% puree). Adds natural fruit sugars
Honey (raw, unpasteurized): Tiny drop (pea-sized) mixed into CGD for appetite stimulation. Use sparingly - high sugar
Waxworms/Superworms: 1-2 worms monthly as high-fat treat. DO NOT use as regular feeders (causes obesity)
Hornworms: Excellent hydration treat (85% water), low fat, high calcium. 1-2 medium hornworms every 2-3 weeks

content.content: Foods to AVOID: NEVER offer dairy products (geckos are lactose intolerant), avocado (toxic), citrus fruits (too acidic), raw meat (bacteria risk), dog/cat food (wrong nutrient ratios), or baby food with additives/preservatives. Stick to CGD, approved insects, and occasional safe treats only.

rows: Flavor pickiness, temperature too cold (<70F), stress, breeding season
Rotate CGD flavors (try Pangea Watermelon, Repashy Mango), warm CGD to room temp before offering, check temperatures, add tiny drop honey to stimulate appetite, reduce handling for 3-5 days
Overfed CGD (too full), insect size too large, gecko not hungry, low temperatures
Skip next CGD feeding to increase hunger, offer smaller insects, ensure basking zone 82-85F (metabolism slows when cold), try different insect type (dubia vs crickets)
Parasites (coccidia, pinworms), improper temperatures, metabolic bone disease (MBD)
Fecal test by exotic vet, verify basking 82-85F and cool 70-75F, check calcium supplementation schedule, increase feeding frequency
Overfeeding CGD, too many insects, high-fat feeders (waxworms, superworms)
Reduce CGD to every 3 days for adults, limit insects to 1x weekly, eliminate waxworms/superworms, increase enclosure enrichment for activity
Give 5-7 days to acclimate without handling, maintain consistent feeding schedule, offer favorite CGD flavor, ensure proper temperatures
Shipping stress, temperature stress during transport, dehydration
Prioritize hydration first (mist heavily, offer water droplets), wait 48 hours before offering food, keep in quiet location, check temps immediately
Calcium deficiency (pica behavior), boredom, mistaking for food
Increase calcium dusting frequency, add more climbing enrichment, ensure insects not falling to substrate during feeding, consider magnetic feeding ledge

content.content: Gargoyle geckos often drink while eating or immediately after. Ensure fresh water available during feeding times.

items: Water Dish: Always provide shallow water dish (<1 inch deep) with fresh water. Change daily
Misting During Feeding: Lightly mist enclosure before offering CGD (6-9 PM). Geckos lick water droplets while feeding
CGD Hydration: Mixed CGD contains 60-65% water - contributes significantly to hydration
Dehydration Signs: Sunken eyes, wrinkled skin, lethargy, stuck shed. Increase misting to 3x daily if detected
Humidity Target: Maintain 60-80% humidity for proper hydration and appetite

content.content: Feeding Success Summary: Feed juveniles CGD daily + insects 1-2x weekly. Feed adults CGD every 2-3 days + insects 1x weekly. Always dust insects with calcium WITHOUT D3 (if using UVB). Rotate CGD flavors monthly to prevent pickiness. Remove uneaten CGD after 24 hours. Gut-load insects 48 hours before feeding. Monitor weight monthly - adjust portions if gaining/losing too fast.
